items.title: ValueConstraintError with AES encryption
items.body:
Hi,

We are using pysnmp 4.4.4 and pycryptodomex 3.72 versions in our application.

We are currently facing following issue when we use AES 128 bit encryption:

ValueConstraintError('<ConstraintsIntersection object at 0x7f22c5455278 consts <ValueSizeConstraint object at 0x7f22cb29c160 consts 0, 65535>, <ValueSizeConstraint object at 0x7f22c5445710 consts 0, 255>, <ValueSizeConstraint object at 0x7f22c5455240 consts 1, 32>> failed at: ValueConstraintError("<ValueSizeConstraint object at 0x7f22c5455240 consts 1, 32> failed at: ValueConstraintError(b\'\',)",) at SnmpAdminString',)>

Now another mystry for me is that the OID we are fetching here is System-name OID (1.3.6.1.2.1.1.5) which is of type 'String' but here it is failing in SnmpAdminString. 

Also, we have tried it with DES, v2c and it seems to work fine. 

I also captured the packet using tcpdump and decrypted it in wireshark using same credentials to check the data and wireshark was able to decrypt it without any issues and showed me the right data.

I also enabled pysnmp debug but couldn't get any more information on identifying what could be going wrong here.

Will really appreciate if anyone has a fix for this or can suggest a workaround.

Also, please let me know if you need any more information.

Regards,
Bharat

items.title: Using Pysnmp with Multiprocessing or Threading
http://mibs.snmplabs.com/asn1/IEEE8023-LAG-MIB is out of date
items.body:
file there is updated "201412180000Z".

Later MIB at http://www.ieee802.org/1/files/public/MIBs/IEEE8023-LAG-MIB-201610120000Z.txt is updated "201610120000Z"

Example significant changes that cause validation failures:

```
dot3adAggPortActorSystemPriority OBJECT-TYPE
    SYNTAX       Integer32 (0..255)
    MAX-ACCESS   read-write
    STATUS       current
    DESCRIPTION
        "A 2-octet read-write value used to define the priority
        value associated with the Actor's System ID."
    REFERENCE
        "7.3.2.1.2"
    ::= { dot3adAggPortEntry 2 }
```

vs.
```
dot3adAggPortActorSystemPriority OBJECT-TYPE
    SYNTAX       Integer32 (0..65535)
    MAX-ACCESS   read-write
    STATUS       current
    DESCRIPTION
        "A 2-octet read-write value used to define the priority
        value associated with the Actor's System ID."
    REFERENCE
        "7.3.2.1.2"
    ::= { dot3adAggPortEntry 2 }
```

items.title: SNMP Trap OID string value is getting converted to hex
items.body:
Hi,
I'm trying to write a script that sends a trap when a syslog message is received.
When i use a short literal string it works well, but when the string gets bigger or I use a string variable as the value of and OID, the trap is sent with the value converted to hex.

Here is a sample of my code.

```
from pysnmp import debug
from pysnmp.entity import engine, config
from pysnmp.carrier.asyncore.dgram import udp
from pysnmp.entity.rfc3413 import ntforg
from pysnmp.proto.api import v2c

src_host = "192.168.1.100" 
dst_host = "192.168.1.101"
dst_port = 162
syslog_msg = ("Dec 13 21:19:10 amt-srv-co7 This is a sylog test message")

snmp_engine = engine.SnmpEngine()
config.addV1System(snmp_engine, "my-area", "public", transportTag="all-my-managers")
config.addTargetParams(snmp_engine, "my-creds", "my-area", "noAuthNoPriv", 1)
config.addTransport(snmp_engine, udp.domainName, udp.UdpSocketTransport().openClientMode())
config.addTargetAddr(snmp_engine, "my-nms", udp.domainName, (dst_host, dst_port), "my-creds", tagList="all-my-managers", sourceAddress=(src_host, 0))
config.addNotificationTarget(snmp_engine, "my-notification", "my-filter", "all-my-managers", "trap")
config.addContext(snmp_engine, "")
config.addVacmUser(snmp_engine, 2, "my-area", "noAuthNoPriv", (), (), (1,3,6))
ntf_org = ntforg.NotificationOriginator()

ostr = v2c.OctetString(syslog_msg) #THE PROBLEM IS HERE!
# ostr = v2c.OctetString("Short message is OK")
# ostr = v2c.OctetString("A long message, not much longer than is converted to a hex string.")

varBinds = [((1, 3, 6, 1, 6, 3, 1, 1, 4, 1, 0), v2c.ObjectIdentifier((1, 3, 6, 1, 2, 1, 192, 0, 1))), ((1, 3, 6, 1, 2, 1, 192, 1, 2, 1, 11), ostr)]

send_request_handle = ntf_org.sendVarBinds(snmp_engine, "my-notification", None, "", varBinds, cb_fun)

snmp_engine.transportDispatcher.runDispatcher()
```
I tried changing de OID to something that would represent a string, but I get the same issue.

I believe that the issue happen when ntf_org.sendVarBinds is called... but maybe there is jist something I'm doing wrong.

Also if I just run a snmptrap from the CL I get the text in string format.

`snmptrap -v 2c -c public 192.168.1.101 '1.3.6.1.6.3.1.1.4.1.0' '1.3.6.1.2.1.192.0.1' '1.3.6.1.2.1.192.1.2.11' s 'Dec 13 21:19:10 amt-srv-co7 This is a sylog test message'
`

But I get different Trap Types.
For the script I get a Trap Type of 1.3.6.1.2.1.192.1.2.1.6.11
For the snmptrap command I get 1.3.6.1.2.1.6.192
 
Can you guys give me a tip?

Thanks!

items.title: How to query an APC UPS
items.body:
I can't figure out how to decipher the documentation to determine how to accomplish querying an APC UPS.

I tried hlapi.getCmd:

```
from pysnmp.hlapi import *

errorIndication, errorStatus, errorIndex, snmpVal = getCmd(
	SnmpEngine(),
	UsmUserData(
            userName=snmpAuthUser,
	    authKey=snmpAuthPass,
	    authProtocol=authProtocol,
	    privKey=snmpPrivPass,
	),
        UdpTransportTarget((snmpHost, 161)),
	ContextData(),
        ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('1.3.6.1.4.1.318.1.1.1.2.2.3', TimeTicks))
)
```

This give me the error:

```
 MibNotFoundError: MIB file "1.3.6.1.4.1.318.1.1.1.2.2.3.py[co]" not found in search path.
```

I looked in the folder where the module is installed and found python files not mib files, however internet search eventually lead me to mibdump.py. I tried the following

```
mibdump.py --mib-source=file:///source/powernet431.mib  \
    --destination-directory=/home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pysnmp/smi/mibs apc
```

I got the following output:

```
> Source MIB repositories: file:///source/powernet431.mib
> Borrow missing/failed MIBs from: http://mibs.snmplabs.com/pysnmp/notexts/@mib@
> Existing/compiled MIB locations: pysnmp.smi.mibs, pysnmp_mibs
> Compiled MIBs destination directory: /home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pysnmp/smi/mibs
> MIBs excluded from code generation: INET-ADDRESS-MIB, PYSNMP-USM-MIB, RFC-1212, RFC-1215, RFC1065-SMI, RFC1155-SMI, RFC1158-MIB, RFC1213-MIB, SNMP-FRAMEWORK-MIB, SNMP-TARGET-MIB, SNMPv2-CONF, SNMPv2-SMI, SNMPv2-TC, SNMPv2-TM, TRANSPORT-ADDRESS-MIB
> MIBs to compile: apc
> Destination format: pysnmp
> Parser grammar cache directory: not used
> Also compile all relevant MIBs: yes
> Rebuild MIBs regardless of age: no
> Dry run mode: no
> Create/update MIBs: yes
> Byte-compile Python modules: yes (optimization level no)
> Ignore compilation errors: no
> Generate OID->MIB index: no
> Generate texts in MIBs: no
> Keep original texts layout: no
> Try various file names while searching for MIB module: yes
> Created/updated MIBs:
> Pre-compiled MIBs borrowed:
> Up to date MIBs:
> Missing source MIBs: apc
> Ignored MIBs:
> Failed MIBs:
```

The apc MIB isn't missing. It is in the source file I referenced. There were no additional files in /home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pysnmp/smi/mibs apc.

I did some more internet searching and found another suggestion:

```
from pysnmp.entity.rfc3413.oneliner import cmdgen

cmdGen = cmdgen.CommandGenerator()

errorIndication, errorStatus, errorIndex, snmpVal = cmdGen.getCmd(
	cmdgen.UsmUserData(
		snmpAuthUser,
		authKey=snmpAuthPro,
		authProtocol=authProtocol,
		privProtocol=privProtocol,
		privKey=snmpPrivPass
	),
	cmdgen.UdpTransportTarget((snmpHost, 161),snmpTimeout),
	'1.3.6.1.4.1.318.1.1.1.2.2.3'
)
```

I get the following error:

```
> pysnmp.smi.error.WrongValueError: WrongValueError({'idx': 1, 'name': (1, 3, 6, 1, 4, 1, 20408, 3, 1, 1, 1, 2, 1, 2, 97, 112, 99, 113, 117, 101, 114, 121), 'msg': WrongValueError()})
```

I also tried:

```
from pysnmp.entity.rfc3413.oneliner import cmdgen

cmdGen = cmdgen.CommandGenerator()

errorIndication, errorStatus, errorIndex, snmpVal = cmdGen.getCmd(
	cmdgen.UsmUserData(
		snmpAuthUser,
		authKey=snmpAuthPro,
		authProtocol=authProtocol,
		privProtocol=privProtocol,
		privKey=snmpPrivPass
	),
	cmdgen.UdpTransportTarget((snmpHost, 161),snmpTimeout),
	cmdgen.ObjectType(cmdgen.ObjectIdentity('1.3.6.1.4.1.318.1.1.1.2.2.3'),cmdgen.TimeTicks)
)
```

I got the same error.

I tried searching for what additional options are available for cmdgen.getCmd to see what other options there are to possibly address the issue, but I can't find it.  I have zero clue how to resolve the issue that I have. Please help.

items.title: Trap decoder for python 2.7
items.body:
Hi,

I've been working with a trap decoder for python 2.7. I got it to work with python 3.6.8, but when I'm trying to verify the snmp version I get the error message:

`TypeError: ord() expected string of length 1, but int found`

My message is a list of ints, which seems to work for python 3, but what kind of input should I use in case of python 2.7? I tried to convert the list into hex values and then create a list of singular bytes, but it did not solve the issue.

items.title: minor mistake in privProtocol docs
items.body:
Was reading through the docs at: http://snmplabs.com/pysnmp/docs/api-reference.html#pysnmp.hlapi.UsmUserData

and noticed that under privProtocol, it says:
usmNoPrivProtocol (default is authKey not given)
usmDESPrivProtocol (default if authKey is given)

I believe both of those authKey should be privKey instead.

items.title: No suitable module found : 'CISCO-CONFIG-COPY-MIB'
items.body:
I want to use `pysnmp` to execute `snmp` command 
`snmpset -c public -v 2c 192.168.1.1 1.3.6.1.4.1.9.9.96.1.1.1.1.2.336 i 1`, 

where `1.3.6.1.4.1.9.9.96.1.1.1.1.2` is OID of `ccCopyProtocol` in `CISCO-CONFIG-COPY-MIB`. 
`336` is a random number.(Each time you copy to or from a device using SNMP, choose a random number. This number creates a row instance. It must be the same everywhere in your command.)

So I write this code:

```
g = setCmd(
    SnmpEngine(),
    CommunityData('public', mpModel=1),
    UdpTransportTarget(('192.168.1.1', 161)),
    ContextData(),
    ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('CISCO-CONFIG-COPY-MIB', 'ccCopyProtocol', 2), '1'))

next(g)
```

when I run this code, it report error:

```
No suitable module found : 'CISCO-CONFIG-COPY-MIB'
```

Could anyone help me deal with this error ?

furthermore, how can I implement the random number (`336`) in code?

items.title: Unable to negotiate authoritative SNMP engine ID
items.body:
I was unable to get getcmd response from cisco router in gns3, where as i was able to get reply from a juniper olive device. "No SNMP response received before timeout" is the reply. When i tried to capture the packets in wire shark, i found the report pdu from juniper device contains the authoritative engine id, where as from cisco device, it was missing. Python code which i am running (taken from the examples), is below:

```
from pysnmp.hlapi import *

errorIndication, errorStatus, errorIndex, varBinds = next(
    getCmd(SnmpEngine(),
           UsmUserData('noauthuser'),
           UdpTransportTarget(('10.205.96.1', 161)),
           ContextData(),
           ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysDescr', 0)))
)

if errorIndication:
    print(errorIndication)
elif errorStatus:
    print('%s at %s' % (errorStatus.prettyPrint(),
                        errorIndex and varBinds[int(errorIndex) - 1][0] or '?'))
else:
    for varBind in varBinds:
        print(' = '.join([x.prettyPrint() for x in varBind]))
```

So can anyone throw some light on why it happens so. When i tried to run the 'get' command on the said cisco device by using GetSnmp.exe from snmpsoft.com, i am getting the proper response. Only when using the above code, i was unable to get any response.

items.title: Implementing custom scalar Mib objects
items.body:
Hi,

I am implementing my own custom scalar Mib object and would like to understand the behavior that I am seeing. Following the guide here [implementing-scalar-mib-objects](http://snmplabs.com/pysnmp/examples/v3arch/asyncore/agent/cmdrsp/agent-side-mib-implementations.html#implementing-scalar-mib-objects) I have my Mib implementation up and running and can query the agent as expected.

However, if I move the following code into its own module:

```python
class MyStaticMibScalarInstance(MibScalarInstance):
    # noinspection PyUnusedLocal,PyUnusedLocal
    def getValue(self, name, idx):
        return self.getSyntax().clone(
            'Python %s running on a %s platform' % (sys.version, sys.platform)
        )
```

and import the MibScalarInstance definition, in the same module, as so:

```python
from pysnmp.smi.builder import MibBuilder

MibScalarInstance, = MibBuilder().importSymbols('SNMPv2-SMI', 'MibScalarInstance') 
```

When, back in the my SNMP engine's code, I export my symbol I can no longer snmpget or snmpwalk MyStaticMibScalarInstance - I receive the following response:

```
 No Such Object available on this agent at this OID
```

The method that I am currently using, is to import the MibScalarInstance SNMPv2-SMI symbol using the MibBuilder attached to my SNMP Engine:

```python
     self.snmp_engine = engine.SnmpEngine()
     self.snmp_context = context.SnmpContext(self.snmp_engine)
     self.mib_builder = self.snmp_context.getMibInstrum().getMibBuilder()
     self.mib_scalar, self.mib_scalar_instance, = self.mib_builder.importSymbols(
         'SNMPv2-SMI', 'MibScalar', 'MibScalarInstance')
``` 

Then, in the separate module where I have my custom scalar Mib object using a function to subclass the MibScalarInstance definition:

```python
def create_custom_mib_scalar_instance(superclass, name):

    class MyStaticMibScalarInstance(superclass):

        maxAccess = 'readWrite'

        def __init__(self, name):

            super(MyStaticMibScalarInstance, self).__init__(
                      name, (0,), v2c.OctetString())

        # noinspection PyUnusedLocal,PyUnusedLocal
        def getValue(self, name, idx):
            return self.getSyntax().clone(
                'Python %s running on a %s platform' % (sys.version, sys.platform)
            )

    return MyStaticMibScalarInstance(name)
```

Finally, back in the SNMP engine code I can do the following:

```python
 self.mib_builder.exportSymbols(
            '__MY_MIB',
            self.mib_scalar((1, 3, 6, 1, 5, 2), v2c.OctetString()),
            create_custom_mib_scalar_instance(
                self.mib_scalar_instance, (1, 3, 6, 1, 5, 2))
)
``` 

and I can successfully snmpget my custom scalar Mib object:

```
iso.3.6.1.5.2.0 = STRING: "Python 2.7.15+ (default, Nov 27 2018, 23:36:35) 
[GCC 7.3.0] running on a linux2 platform"
```

Would you kindly explain the behavior I am seeing and whether the function/subclass approach is best?

items.title: Set Request Error: Requested OID is out of MIB view
items.body:
Hello,

I am using pySNMP 4.4.9 and Python 3.7

I have implemented an SNMP Agent that keeps track of a custom MIB. When I issue a Set Request at any of the OIDs in my MIB, the callback function in my SNMP Manager returns a “notWritable” error status. The OIDs are valid because I can issue a Get Request to them with no problem. The MAX-ACCESS of my OIDs are also read-write so I should be able to write to them.
 
I stepped into the pySNMP code and I saw that the error originates from the call to acFun when the writeTest method of the MibScalar class tests the access to the OID (line 631 in SNMPv2-SMI.py):

``` Python
def writeTest(self, name, val, idx, acInfo):
    acFun, acCtx = acInfo
    if name == self.name:
        raise error.NoAccessError(idx=idx, name=name)
    if acFun:
        if self.maxAccess not in ('readwrite', 'readcreate') or \
                acFun(name, self.syntax, idx, 'write', acCtx):
            raise error.NotWritableError(idx=idx, name=name)
    MibTree.writeTest(self, name, val, idx, acInfo)

```
 Stepping into acFun, I see that the call below fails with the “Requested OID is out of MIB view” error:

``` Python
snmpEngine.accessControlModel[self.acmID].isAccessAllowed(
    snmpEngine, securityModel, securityName,
    securityLevel, viewType, contextName, name
)
```
This call is made in the _verifyAccess method of the CommandResponder (line 234 in cmdrsp.py). 

What am I missing? What does the error “Requested OID is out of MIB view” mean?

I load the MIB using the following code in my Agent:
``` Python
mib_builder = self._snmpContext.getMibInstrum().getMibBuilder()
        mib_sources = mib_builder.getMibSources() + (builder.DirMibSource('./../../../MIBS/'),)
        mib_builder.setMibSources(*mib_sources)

        # our variables will subclass this since we only have scalar types
        # can't load this type directly, need to import it
        mib_scalar_instance, = mib_builder.importSymbols('SNMPv2-SMI',
                                                         'MibScalarInstance')
        # export our custom mib
       # mib_object contains MIB name, the variable to interact with, a getter and setter function
       # to read and write to the MIB
        for mib_object in mib_objects:
            next_var, = mib_builder.importSymbols(mib_object.mibName,
                                                  mib_object.objectType)
            instance = create_variable(mib_scalar_instance,
                                       mib_object.value_get_func,
                                       mib_object.value_set_func,
                                       next_var.name, (0,),
                                       next_var.syntax)
            # need to export as <var name>Instance
            instance_dict = {str(next_var.name)+"Instance": instance}
            mib_builder.exportSymbols(mib_object.mibName,
                                      **instance_dict)
```

create_variable class overwrites methods from the MibScalarInstance object but the writeTest and writeCommit methods are never called when the set request is made.
``` Python
def create_variable(super_class, get_value, set_value, *args):
    class Var(super_class):
        def readGet(self, name, *args):
            return name, self.syntax.clone(get_value())

        def writeTest(self, name, *args):
            print(" Testing var...")

        def writeCommit(self, name, val, *args):
            print(" Setting var...")
            set_value(val)
    return Var(*args)
```

Thanks for your help!

David

```
	SNMPv2-SMI::enterprises.30140.1.36 Enterprise Specific Trap (1000) Uptime: 9 days, 6:56:24.62
	**IF-MIB::ifPhysAddress[1] = STRING: 0:a:14:85:62:e**	IF-MIB::ifInOctets[2] = Counter32: 91106744	IF-MIB::ifOutOctets[2] = Counter32: 35932608	
...`
```
Because ifPhysAddress is of type OCTET STRING, my first attempt to simulate the trap used
the syntax `OctetString('00:0A:14:00:00:00')`. But this doesn't work. An OctetString (with default parameter _strValue_) appears on the wire as the encoded hex characters:
```
0000: 30 82 02 57  02 01 00 04  06 70 75 62  6C 69 63 A4    0..W.....public.
0016: 82 02 48 06  0A 2B 06 01  04 01 81 EB  3C 01 23 40    ..H..+......<.#@

0064: 01 **04 11 30  30 3A 30 41  3A 31 34 3A  30 30 3A 30    ...00:0A:14:00:0
0080: 30 3A 30 30**  30 0F 06 0A  2B 06 01 02  01 02 02 01    0:000...+.......
0096: 0A 02 02 01  00 30 0F 06  0A 2B 06 01  02 01 02 02    .....0...+......
...
2019-05-29 17:35:49 0.0.0.0(via UDP: [127.0.0.1]:50276->[127.0.0.1]:162) TRAP, SNMP v1, community public
	SNMPv2-SMI::enterprises.30140.1.35 Enterprise Specific Trap (1000) Uptime: 0:00:00.00
	**IF-MIB::ifPhysAddress[1] = STRING: 30:30:3a:30:41:3a:31:34:3a:30:30:3a:30:30:3a:30:30**	
...`

In order to get it to work, I have to use the syntax `OctetString(hexValue='000A14000000')`:
`0000: 30 82 02 4C  02 01 00 04  06 70 75 62  6C 69 63 A4    0..L.....public.
0016: 82 02 3D 06  0A 2B 06 01  04 01 81 EB  3C 01 23 40    ..=..+......<.#@
0032: 04 00 00 00  00 02 01 06  02 02 03 E8  43 01 00 30    ............C..0
0048: 82 02 1D 30  14 06 0A 2B  06 01 02 01  02 02 01 06    ...0...+........

...
2019-05-29 17:48:21 0.0.0.0(via UDP: [127.0.0.1]:49058->[127.0.0.1]:162) TRAP, SNMP v1, community public

	**IF-MIB::ifPhysAddress[1] = STRING: 0:a:14:0:0:0**	
...`
```
I guess this makes sense, because ifPhysAddress is a MAC address and therefore is always composed of hex characters. But I'm worried that I am missing something. Do all SNMP agents treat ifPhysAddress as raw hex? Or are there agents (devices) that treat ifPhysAddress as an actual string?

items.title: AsynccoreDispatcher catches SystemExit
items.body:
I have an application using pysnmp with a daemon that exits in response to SIGTERM by calling sys.exit from a signal handler.  I have seen unclean or failed exits from it due to pysnmp.carrier.asyncore.AsyncoreDispatcher.runDispatcher catching SystemExit.  The function includes specific handling for KeyboardInterrupt, but not for SystemExit,

I would suggest changing the bare except: to except Exception: and removing the special case for KeyboardInterrupt.

items.title: Loading uncompiled MIB files.
items.body:
I'm stumped on what I would think would be a simple task. The sample script "SNMP MIB browser" gives every indication that `compiler.addMibCompiler(mibBuilder, sources=['/usr/share/snmp/mibs'])` adds a MIB compiler to load uncompiled MIBs and that `mibBuilder.addMibSources(builder.DirMibSource('/opt/pysnmp_mibs'))` is to add a source containing pre-compiled MIBs. 

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python
from pysnmp import debug
from pysnmp.smi import builder, view, compiler, rfc1902, error

def main():
#    debug.setLogger(debug.Debug('all'))
    mibBuilder = builder.MibBuilder()
    compiler.addMibCompiler(mibBuilder, sources = ['file:///home/user/python-udp/MIBs', ])
    mibBuilder.loadModules('SNMPv2-SMI')
    mibBuilder.loadModules('SNMPv2-TC')
    mibBuilder.loadModules('INET-ADDRESS-MIB')
    mibBuilder.loadModules('IANAifType-MIB')
    mibViewController = view.MibViewController(mibBuilder)
    modName = mibViewController.getFirstModuleName()
    while 1:
        if modName: print(modName)
        try:
            modName = mibViewController.getNextModuleName(modName)
        except error.SmiError:
            break
    return

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
```
The `loadModules()` all work until the one to load `IANAifType-MIB` which is the first one which isn't included in pysnmp itself. At no point does it give any indication that it's looking in the directory I specified. I've tried numerous variations on the theme but cannot find anything which works. items.title: The way exceptions are caught/handled/re raised in AsyncoreDispatcher.runDispatcher()
Performance issues when upgrading from PySNMP 2.0.9
items.body:
Continuing our [discussion from the PureSNMP tracker](https://github.com/exhuma/puresnmp/issues/47).

While working to upgrade an old internal application, I have found that modern PySNMP is about twice as slow as PySNMP 2.0.9. I recognize that part/most/all of the inefficiency I am experiencing could be my lack of understanding of the modern PySNMP API.

Here's the code I am using for comparison.

With PySNMP 2.0.9:

```
import pysnmp.asn1 
import pysnmp.v2c
import pysnmp.role

if True:

    def getbulk(client, base_oid, dst, comm):
        # Create a SNMP request&response objects
        req = pysnmp.v2c.GETBULKREQUEST(community=comm, non_repeaters=0, max_repetitions=256)
        rsp = pysnmp.v2c.RESPONSE()

        # Store table headers
        head_oid = pysnmp.asn1.OBJECTID(base_oid)

        # BER encode initial SNMP Object IDs to query
        encoded_oids = [ head_oid.encode() ]

        retval = {}
        # Traverse agent MIB
        while 1:
            # Encode SNMP request message and try to send it to SNMP agent
            # and receive a response
            (answer, src) = client.send_and_receive(req.encode(encoded_oids=encoded_oids),dst)

            # Attempt to decode SNMP response
            rsp.decode(answer)

            # Make sure response matches request (request IDs, communities, etc)
            if False and req != rsp:
                raise 'Unmatched response: %s vs %s' % (str(req), str(rsp))

            # Decode BER encoded Object IDs.
            oids = map(lambda x: x[0], map(pysnmp.asn1.OBJECTID().decode, rsp['encoded_oids']))

            # Decode BER encoded values associated with Object IDs.
            vals = map(lambda x: x[0](), map(pysnmp.asn1.decode, rsp['encoded_vals']))

            # Check for remote SNMP agent failure
            if rsp['error_status']:
                # SNMP agent reports 'no such name' when walk is over XXX
                if rsp['error_status'] == 2:
                    # One of the tables exceeded
                    for l in oids, vals, head_oids:
                        del l[rsp['error_index']-1]
                else:
                    raise 'SNMP error #' + str(rsp['error_status']) + ' for OID #' + str(rsp['error_index'])
        
            # Cut OID list by fisrt non-prefix OID
            for idx in range(len(oids)):
                if not head_oid.isaprefix(oids[idx]):
                    oids = oids[:idx]
                    vals = vals[:idx]
                    break

            if not oids:
                break

            # Print out results
            for (oid, val) in map(None, oids, vals):
                retval[oid] = val

            # BER encode next SNMP Object IDs to query
            encoded_oids = map(pysnmp.asn1.OBJECTID().encode, oids[-1:])

            # Update request object
            req['request_id'] = req['request_id'] + 1
        return retval

    def getbulktrimmed(client, base_oid, dst, comm):
        trim = len(base_oid) + 1
        retval = {}
        temp = getbulk(client, base_oid, dst, comm)
        for k,v in temp.iteritems():
            newk = k[trim:]
            retval[newk] = v
        return retval


if __name__ == '__main__':
    dot1dTpFdbPort = '.1.3.6.1.2.1.17.4.3.1.2'
    switch_ips = [] #redacted for brevity

    snmpclient = pysnmp.role.manager()
    snmpclient.timeout = 3
    comm = 'public'
    port = 161

    for switch in switch_ips:
        mactable = getbulktrimmed(snmpclient, dot1dTpFdbPort, (switch, port), comm)
        #print(switch,mactable)
        print(switch)

```

 With modern PySNMP:

```
from pysnmp.hlapi import *

def getbulktrimmed(snmpengine, base_oid, dst, comm):
    result = {}
    match_oid = base_oid.strip('.') + '.'
    trim_len = len(match_oid)
    transport = UdpTransportTarget(dst)
    for (errorIndication,
         errorStatus,
         errorIndex,
         varBinds) in bulkCmd(snmpengine,
                              comm,
                              transport,
                              ContextData(),
                              0, 50,
                              ObjectType(ObjectIdentity(base_oid)),
                              lexicographicMode=False
                              ):

        if errorIndication:
            print(errorIndication)
            break
        elif errorStatus:
            print('%s at %s' % (errorStatus.prettyPrint(),
                                errorIndex and varBinds[int(errorIndex) - 1][0] or '?'))
            break
        else:
            for varBind in varBinds:
                oid = str(varBind[0])
                if oid.startswith(match_oid):
                    result[oid[trim_len:]] = int(varBind[1])
                else:
                    print(varBind[0].prettyPrint())

    return result

if __name__ == '__main__':
    dot1dTpFdbPort = '.1.3.6.1.2.1.17.4.3.1.2'
    switch_ips = [] #redacted for brevity

    snmpengine = SnmpEngine()
    comm = CommunityData('public', mpModel=1)
    port = 161
    base_oid = dot1dTpFdbPort

    for switch in switch_ips:
        mactable = getbulktrimmed(snmpengine, base_oid, (switch, port), comm)
        #print(switch,mactable)
        print(switch)
```

items.title: Issue walking an oid
items.body:
Hello,

I'm build a script to get statuses of docsis cable modem.
Using the following OID  1.3.6.1.2.1.10.127.1.3.3.1.9  I'm able to pick data I need for my script.

My issue is when I achieved a walk with  pysnmp and  the script loop finish to read whole children of OID: 1.3.6.1.2.1.10.127.1.3.3.1.9 , pysnmp jump to  OID: 1.3.6.1.2.1.10.127.1.3.3.1.10 instead of exit.

How can I keep snmp walking in the current scope
Linux snmpwalk command line works as expected.

Regards

items.title: Bug in RFC1158-MIB.py, leading to "NameError: name 'snmpInReadOnlys' is not defined"
items.body:
In pysnmp 4.4.4, there seems to be a bug in RFC1158-MIB.py: https://github.com/etingof/pysnmp/blob/4d57bdbbfe08d387ac844824075c2ebc366b88a8/pysnmp/smi/mibs/RFC1158-MIB.py#L19-L20

In the second line, `snmpInReadOnlys` should probably be `snmpOutReadOnlys`, otherwise one gets a `NameError` quite easily:

```python
from pysnmp.smi.builder import MibBuilder
b = MibBuilder()
b.loadTexts = True
b.loadModules()
```
results in
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/omd/sites/heute/lib/python/pysnmp/smi/builder.py", line 368, in loadModules
    self.loadModule(modName, **userCtx)
  File "/omd/sites/heute/lib/python/pysnmp/smi/builder.py", line 336, in loadModule
    'MIB module \"%s\" load error: %s' % (modPath, traceback.format_exception(*sys.exc_info()))
pysnmp.smi.error.MibLoadError: MIB module "/omd/sites/heute/lib/python/pysnmp/smi/mibs/RFC1158-MIB.pyc" load error: ['Traceback (most recent call last):\n', '  File "/omd/sites/heute/lib/python/pysnmp/smi/builder.py", line 331, in loadModule\n    exec (modData, g)\n', '  File "/lib/python/pysnmp/smi/mibs/RFC1158-MIB.py", line 20, in <module>\n', "NameError: name 'snmpInReadOnlys' is not defined\n"]
```

I have no clue how RFC1158-MIB.py is generated, it could as well be a bug in pysmi...

items.title: Getting valid values from MIB
items.body:
Is there a way to obtain the valid values of a certain scalar?
For instance, I've got this code in a Python MIB module MYMODULE :

```
class SomeStatus(TextualConvention, Integer32):
    status = 'current'
    subtypeSpec = Integer32.subtypeSpec + SingleValueConstraint(1, 2, 3)
    namedValues = NamedValues(("initializing", 1), ("running", 2), ("exiting", 3))

[...]

myStatus = MibScalar((1, 3, 6, 1, 4, 1, 8173, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 5), SomeStatus()).setMaxAccess("readwrite")
```
Then, in the manager I create an ObjectType like this:

ObjectType(ObjectIdentity(['MYMODULE', 'myStatus', '0']), **value**).resolveWithMib(__mibView)

I want to get those NamedValues: initializing, running, exiting

Thanks in advance

items.body:

Even after i tried in my code to load modules:
`    mibBuilder = builder.MibBuilder()

    )`

items.title: Resolve Named Value to Variable
items.body:
I have this MIB definition

```
BasicState ::= TEXTUAL-CONVENTION
    STATUS      current
    DESCRIPTION "A description"
    SYNTAX      INTEGER
                {
                    state1 (1),
                    state2 (2),
		    state3 (3)
                }
```
which generates this code with mibdump.py

```
class BasicState(TextualConvention, Integer32):
    status = 'current'
    subtypeSpec = Integer32.subtypeSpec + SingleValueConstraint(1, 2, 3)
    namedValues = NamedValues(("state1", 1), ("state2", 2), ("state3", 3))
```
Is there a way to resolve a value (e.g. 'state1') to a Integer32 variable?
thanks in advance!

items.title: How to encode MibTables using pyasn1 codec encoders
items.body:
Hi!

I am developing code for a NTCIP agent, which is basically SNMP with additional layers. I already have  created the object instances (most part grouped on tables) successfully - but as a requirement I need to encode some of these tables using BER or OER and store in files. Well, the question is:

Considering that pysnmp apparently is built on top of pyasn1 structure, is there a way to (BER) encode a MibTable directly as a sequence? I am stuck trying to do this in an easy way. but it looks like MibTable's are defined as NoneType objects and have no direct links to its rows, so no way for the encoder to know how to navigate through them.

So, I assume the only way to do this is to create manually a SEQUENCE OF object using pyasn1 and add entries by manually navigating through all rows? I mean, for each table I will need to define a pyasn1 structure in order to accomplish this?

Any guidance here will help - I am searching for examples but it looks like no one is interested in encoding tables! I could already encode MibScalarInstance's and it is OK, but when talking about grouping/sequence objects I can't see a way out.

Thank you very much
Luiz Fernando

items.title: Need Help with the steps in making simple  SNMP get request
items.body:
Hi,
I'm new to SNMP, I want to do a simple SNMP get command to a EDVA device, please let me know where I went wrong,

```
from pysnmp.hlapi import *

errorIndication, errorStatus, errorIndex, varBinds = next(
    getCmd(SnmpEngine(),
           CommunityData('public', mpModel=1),
           UdpTransportTarget(('myip', 161)),
           ContextData(),
           ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysDescr', 0)))
)

if errorIndication:
    print(errorIndication)
elif errorStatus:
    print('%s at %s' % (errorStatus.prettyPrint(),
                        errorIndex and varBinds[int(errorIndex) - 1][0] or '?'))
else:
    for varBind in varBinds:
        print(' = '.join([x.prettyPrint() for x in varBind]))
```

If I execute this I'm getting "No SNMP response received before timeout" as output
It seems to be a error in the snmp Engine itself, should I configure something else?

Also don't get what exactly is a MIB, should I load it before executing the above code?

items.title: Implement custom mib snmp agent
items.body:
Hi, Ilya

A few months ago I asked for help on stackoverflow and you told me that I should post here to have more hands-on help with the code. The help you provided back then was very useful, I thank you very much. I implemented some tables succesfully, but I still have some errors with other tables. 

This is the first try, [using as an example](http://snmplabs.com/pysnmp/examples/v3arch/twisted/agent/cmdrsp/agent-side-mib-implementations.html):

```
rowInstanceId = characterEntry.getInstIdFromIndices(2)
        mibInstrumentation = self._snmpContext.getMibInstrum()
        mibInstrumentation.writeVars(
            ((characterNumber.name + rowInstanceId, 12),
             (characterWidth.name + rowInstanceId, 13), 
             (characterBitmap.name + rowInstanceId, 5)    
            )
        )
```

The mib was imported and looks like this

```
characterTable = MibTable((1, 3, 6, 1, 4, 1, 1206, 4, 2, 3, 3, 4), )
if mibBuilder.loadTexts: characterTable.setStatus('mandatory')
characterEntry = MibTableRow((1, 3, 6, 1, 4, 1, 1206, 4, 2, 3, 3, 4, 1), ).setIndexNames((0, "DMS-MIB", "fontIndex"), (0, "DMS-MIB", "characterNumber"))
if mibBuilder.loadTexts: characterEntry.setStatus('mandatory')
characterNumber = MibTableColumn((1, 3, 6, 1, 4, 1, 1206, 4, 2, 3, 3, 4, 1, 1), Integer32().subtype(subtypeSpec=ValueRangeConstraint(1, 65535))).setMaxAccess("readonly")
if mibBuilder.loadTexts: characterNumber.setStatus('mandatory')
characterWidth = MibTableColumn((1, 3, 6, 1, 4, 1, 1206, 4, 2, 3, 3, 4, 1, 2), Integer32().subtype(subtypeSpec=ValueRangeConstraint(0, 255))).setMaxAccess("readwrite")
if mibBuilder.loadTexts: characterWidth.setStatus('mandatory')
characterBitmap = MibTableColumn((1, 3, 6, 1, 4, 1, 1206, 4, 2, 3, 3, 4, 1, 3), OctetString()).setMaxAccess("readwrite")
if mibBuilder.loadTexts: characterBitmap.setStatus('mandatory')
```

This is the error I get and I can't track it source. I am running other tables with the same form and they do work. 

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "dms_agent.py", line 996, in <module>
    agent = SNMPAgent(objects)
  File "dms_agent.py", line 732, in __init__
    (characterBitmap.name + rowInstanceId, 5)    
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pysnmp/smi/instrum.py", line 256, in writeVars
    return self.flipFlopFsm(self.fsmWriteVar, varBinds, acInfo)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pysnmp/smi/instrum.py", line 239, in flipFlopFsm
    raise origExc
pysnmp.smi.error.SmiError: Short OID for index Integer32(subtypeSpec=ConstraintsIntersection(ValueRangeConstraint(-2147483648, 2147483647), ValueRangeConstraint(1, 65535)))
```

I also have some problems implementing scalars that are not Integer.  I override the readGet() function, and get the following error. 

```
;  File "dms_agent.py", line 531, in readGet
    return name, self.getSyntax().clone(getValue())
;TypeError: 'str' object is not callable
```

If you have time to run the program yourself and maybe explain to me where I am going wrong I can provide you the complete source code. I thank you very much for all the help.

items.title: demo agent lists config for unsupported auth protocol / inconsistent naming
items.body:
<http://snmplabs.com/snmpsim/public-snmp-agent-simulator.html> lists

`usr-sha384-aes256 | SHA2 (384/512bit) | authkey1 | AES (256bit) | privkey1`

But sha384 is not a supported. snmpget.py help reports:

`  -a AUTH-PROTOCOL  authentication protocol (MD5|NONE|SHA|SHA128|SHA192|SHA256|SHA512|SHA96)`

and trying to use SHA384:

```
snmpget.py -r 0 -v 3 -u usr-sha384-aes256 -x AES256 -X privkey1 -a SHA384 -A authkey1 -l authPriv 127.0.0.1:1161 sysContact.0
Error: Unknown authentication protocol "SHA384
```

I'm guessing that the config should be for **usr-sha512-aes256**.

Also, the previous line:

`usr-sha256-3des | SHA2 (128/224bit)`

doesn't make sense. 128/224 bits is usmHMAC128SHA224AuthProtocol so the name should be usr-sha224-3des.

It's all a bit confusing because in some cases you are using the key length and in others you are using the mac length.  It really should be "SHA224|SHA256|SHA384|SHA512" or "SHA128|SHA192|SHA256|SHA384". I'd suggest the former, as those are the SHA algorithms defined in RFC 6234 <https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6234> (and the key lengths). Mixing them is confusing, especially for SHA256, which could be the key length (256/192) or the mac length (384/256).

Both Net-SNMP and SNMP Research use the "SHA224|SHA256|SHA384|SHA512" forms.

items.title: TypeError: prettyIn() got an unexpected keyword argument 'namedValues'
items.body:
Hi (and sorry for the bad topic name, i don't know any better),

I have problems polling the SNMP object `CISCO-ENTITY-REDUNDANCY-MIB::ceRedunMbrStatusCurrent`. The method `Bits::clone(...)` in `pysnmp/proto/rfc1902.py`, line 612 throws `TypeError: prettyIn() got an unexpected keyword argument 'namedValues'`. It looks like `self.prettyIn()` is not referring to `Bits::prettyIn()`, but actually to `TextualConvention::prettyIn()`, which doesn't have a parameter `namedValues`, which would be the reason for the exception.

The error occurs on the latest pysnmp 4.4.2, but its working on 4.3.8 (with pyasn1==0.2.3). (4.3.9 throws another error) I guess it has something to do with this commit, although it stops working on earlier versions: https://github.com/etingof/pysnmp/commit/0f32c00d89eae2f86b2282ffc50805e059be5492#diff-2b14f165b1eb70bab6b887073bab16b1

I attached an example script performing a simple bulkwalk on `CISCO-ENTITY-REDUNDANCY-MIB::ceRedunMbrStatusCurrent`. A minimal `public.snmp_rec` file for "snmpsim" and the corresponding MIB file are also attached:
[redun-example-bulkwalk.zip](https://github.com/etingof/pysnmp/files/1510409/redun-example-bulkwalk.zip)



# Prerequisites
## env438:
```
$ pip install pyasn1==0.2.3 pysnmp==4.3.8 pysnmp-mibs
$ pip freeze
ply==3.10
pyasn1==0.2.3
pycryptodome==3.4.7
pysmi==0.2.2
pysnmp==4.3.8
pysnmp-mibs==0.1.6
```

## env439:
```
$ pip install pyasn1==0.2.3 pysnmp==4.3.9 pysnmp-mibs
$ pip freeze
ply==3.10
pyasn1==0.2.3
pycryptodome==3.4.7
pysmi==0.2.2
pysnmp==4.3.9
pysnmp-mibs==0.1.6
```

## env442:
```
$ pip install pysnmp==4.4.2 pysnmp-mibs
$ pip freeze
ply==3.10
pyasn1==0.4.2
pycryptodomex==3.4.7
pysmi==0.2.2
pysnmp==4.4.2
pysnmp-mibs==0.1.6
```

# Running the example script

When I use pysnmp 4.3.8 and pyasn1 0.2.3 the script works as expected:
```
(env438) $ python redun-example-bulkwalk.py
CISCO-ENTITY-REDUNDANCY-MIB::ceRedunMbrStatusCurrent.1.1.0 = standby
CISCO-ENTITY-REDUNDANCY-MIB::ceRedunMbrStatusCurrent.1.1.1 = protectionProvided
```


When updating to 4.3.9 (leaving pyasn1 at 0.2.3) i get:
```
(env439) $ python redun-example-bulkwalk.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "redun-example-bulkwalk.py", line 31, in <module>
    print(' = '.join([x.prettyPrint() for x in varBind]))
  File "redun-example-bulkwalk.py", line 31, in <listcomp>
    print(' = '.join([x.prettyPrint() for x in varBind]))
  File "/Users/kaihil/pysnmp-test-namedValues/env435/lib/python3.5/site-packages/pyasn1/type/base.py", line 336, in prettyPrint
    return self.prettyOut(self._value)
  File "<string>", line 176, in prettyOut
  File "/Users/kaihil/pysnmp-test-namedValues/env435/lib/python3.5/site-packages/pysnmp/proto/rfc1902.py", line 660, in prettyOut
    name = self.__namedValues.getName(i * 8 + 7 - j)
AttributeError: 'CeRedunMbrStatus' object has no attribute '_Bits__namedValues'
```

items.title: SHA2 auth protocols not supported in AES key localization
items.body: The AbstractAesBlumenthal localizekey function does not support the SHA2 auth protocols (which are supported in AbstractAesReeder).

items.title: ObjectType's with MIB resolution disabled
items.body:
I'm working with pysnmp and a vendor device without a MIB.
I would like to just SNMP get some OIDs with SNMPv2 and do some things with the result values.

I'm currently getting this to work by using `pysnmp.entity.rfc3413.oneliner.cmdgen.MibVariable(numeric_dotted_oid_string)` to make an `ObjectIdentity`. I then pass a list of these `ObjectIdentity`'s to a `pysnmp.entity.rfc3413.oneliner.cmdgen.CommandGenerator.getCmd` with the kwarg `lookupMib` set to False.
However, this code path still seems to trigger some MIB resolution to resolve names, which is taking a big performance hit.

Is there some simple way to get get an OID without engaging any kind of MIB loading or resolution?

items.title: Endless retrying when using snmpv3 with privkey and retries set to 1
items.body:
I've run into an issue where my SNMPv3 request doesn't timeout even though the timeout is set to 5 and the number of retries is set to 1.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Download [endless_loop.txt](https://github.com/etingof/pysnmp/files/1434241/endless_loop.txt), rename it to `endless_loop.py` and install pysnmp (I've tested with 4.4.1)
2. Download [1.3.6.1.6.1.1.0.txt](https://github.com/etingof/pysnmp/files/1434247/1.3.6.1.6.1.1.0.txt) and rename it to `1.3.6.1.6.1.1.0.snmprec`
3. Go to the folder where you downloaded the `.snmprec` file and run `docker run --rm --name=endless_loop -v $PWD:/usr/share/snmpsim/data -p 161:161/udp -e EXTRA_FLAGS="--v3-user testing --v3-auth-key authkey1234 --v3-auth-proto SHA --v3-priv-key privkey1234 --v3-priv-proto AES" tvestelind/snmpsim`. This will start a docker container with `snmpsimd` and SNMPv3 configured
4. Run `chmod +x endless_loop.py`
5. Run `docker exec -it enless_loop ip a` to get the ip address
6. Run `./endless_loop.py <ip_address> privkey1234`, it should print some info
7. Run `./endless_loop.py <ip_address> badkey1234`, __it will loop endlessly but it shouldn't, right?__
8. Run `./endless_loop.py <ip_address> badkey1234 --retries=2`, setting number of retries to 2 makes it terminate

I don't have time to debug it right now but I might give a try later.

Cheers,
Tomas

items.title: CVE-2013-7459 :-critical. eap-based buffer overflow in the ALGnew function in block_templace.c in Python Cryptography Toolkit (aka pycrypto
items.body:
We are using pysnmp version 4.3.2 which has pycrypto 2.6.1 as it’s dependency. We have recently identified an open security issue against pycrypto which is  CVE-2013-7459
CVSS score (version 3.0) 9.8. It is ranked as critical. eap-based buffer overflow in the ALGnew function in block_templace.c in Python Cryptography Toolkit (aka pycrypto) allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code as demonstrated by a crafted iv parameter to cryptmsg.py.

I know that pycrypto is no more maintained and that’s the reason why pysnmp has replaced pycrypto with pycrptodome in newer releases. I just want to confirm if this vulnerability affects pysnmp 4.3.2 in anyway? Please note that we don’t use pycrypto directly but only as a dependency of pysnmp. If this issue affects pysnmp , was there a patched version of pysnmp 4.3.2 which has this issue addressed?

items.title: Documentation - Code typo
items.body:
In the section on enabling the debugging output using different flags (pysnmp/docs/source/examples/contents.rst) there is a code snippet which contains a flag 'secmode' which is not a valid flag.

This should be changed to 'secmod'.

items.title: [PATCH] ObjectType.resolveWithMib() has OID detection logic reversed; breaks NetworkAddress() value resolution.
items.body: Commit 9feb2210397a9e81528df3428e47ea4548731e3c introduced an OID-value-to-`ObjectIdentity` resolution logic, but it checks the type in the wrong order: Instead of checking whether the value is of a subtype of OID, it checks whether the value is a *supertype* of OID.  This breaks resolution of `NetworkAddress` values, because `NetworkAddress` is an untagged `Choice` type, and counts as a supertype of OID.

items.title: [PATCH] RFC1213-MIB::atTable indices are not encoded/resolved correctly
items.body:
Version: Branch master at commit 0f32c00d89eae2f86b2282ffc50805e059be5492
 
pysnmp/smi/mibs/RFC1213-MIB.py defines the `atNetAddress` index of `atTable` erroneously as `IpAddress`, while the correct type is `NetworkAddress`.  Since the two types have different OID encoding (`NetworkAddress` is equivalent to the modern `InetAddressType`-`InetAddress` combo and has an extra octet at the beginning which specifies the address type), PySNMP fails to encode or decode `atNetAddress` index.

To reproduce:

```
import pysnmp.debug
from pysnmp.smi.builder import MibBuilder
from pysnmp.smi.view import MibViewController
from pysnmp.smi.rfc1902 import ObjectIdentity
from pysnmp.proto.rfc1155 import IpAddress
from pysnmp.proto.rfc1902 import ObjectName
import user

builder = MibBuilder()
builder.loadModules('RFC1213-MIB')
view = MibViewController(builder)

pysnmp.debug.setLogger(pysnmp.debug.Debug('all'))

ident = ObjectIdentity('RFC1213-MIB', 'atIfIndex', 7, IpAddress('143.248.1.177'))
ident.resolveWithMib(view)
print(ident.getOid())

ident2 = ObjectIdentity(ObjectName('1.3.6.1.2.1.3.1.1.1.7.1.143.248.1.177'))
ident2.resolveWithMib(view)
print(ident2.getMibSymbol())
```

Results in:

```
2017-10-06 10:37:45,703 pysnmp: running pysnmp version 4.4.1
2017-10-06 10:37:45,703 pysnmp: debug category 'all' enabled
2017-10-06 10:37:45,792 pysnmp: trying DirMibSource('/Users/eugene.kim/.pysnmp/mibs')
2017-10-06 10:37:45,792 pysnmp: addMibSources: new MIB sources [ZipMibSource('pysnmp/smi/mibs'), ZipMibSource('pysnmp/smi/mibs/instances'), DirMibSource('pysnmp_mibs'), DirMibSource('/Users/eugene.kim/.pysnmp/mibs')]
2017-10-06 10:37:45,792 pysnmp: indexMib: re-indexing MIB view
2017-10-06 10:37:45,795 pysnmp: getNodeNameByOid: resolved :1.3.6.1.2.1.3.1.1.1 -> ('iso', 'org', 'dod', 'internet', 'mgmt', 'mib-2', 'at', 'atTable', 'atEntry', 'atIfIndex').()
2017-10-06 10:37:45,795 pysnmp: resolved ('RFC1213-MIB', 'atIfIndex', 7, IpAddress(hexValue='8ff801b1')) into prefix ObjectName('1.3.6.1.2.1.3.1.1.1') and suffix ()
2017-10-06 10:37:45,795 pysnmp: getNodeNameByOid: resolved :(1, 3, 6, 1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 1) -> ('iso', 'org', 'dod', 'internet', 'mgmt', 'mib-2', 'at', 'atTable', 'atEntry').()
2017-10-06 10:37:45,795 pysnmp: resolved indices are (Integer32(7), IpAddress(hexValue='8ff801b1'))
1.3.6.1.2.1.3.1.1.1.7.143.248.1.177
2017-10-06 10:37:45,795 pysnmp: resolving 1.3.6.1.2.1.3.1.1.1.7.1.143.248.1.177 as OID or label
2017-10-06 10:37:45,796 pysnmp: getNodeNameByOid: resolved :1.3.6.1.2.1.3.1.1.1.7.1.143.248.1.177 -> ('iso', 'org', 'dod', 'internet', 'mgmt', 'mib-2', 'at', 'atTable', 'atEntry', 'atIfIndex').7.1.143.248.1.177
2017-10-06 10:37:45,796 pysnmp: resolved (ObjectName('1.3.6.1.2.1.3.1.1.1.7.1.143.248.1.177'),) into prefix ObjectName('1.3.6.1.2.1.3.1.1.1') and suffix ObjectName('7.1.143.248.1.177')
2017-10-06 10:37:45,796 pysnmp: getNodeNameByOid: resolved :1.3.6.1.2.1.3.1.1.1 -> ('iso', 'org', 'dod', 'internet', 'mgmt', 'mib-2', 'at', 'atTable', 'atEntry', 'atIfIndex').()
2017-10-06 10:37:45,796 pysnmp: resolved prefix ObjectName('1.3.6.1.2.1.3.1.1.1') into MIB node MibTableColumn((1, 3, 6, 1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 1, 1), Integer32())
2017-10-06 10:37:45,796 pysnmp: getNodeNameByOid: resolved :(1, 3, 6, 1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 1) -> ('iso', 'org', 'dod', 'internet', 'mgmt', 'mib-2', 'at', 'atTable', 'atEntry').()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/opt/local/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/runpy.py", line 193, in _run_module_as_main
    "__main__", mod_spec)
  File "/opt/local/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/runpy.py", line 85, in _run_code
    exec(code, run_globals)
  File "/Users/eugene.kim/Work/ESI/snmp2es/z.py", line 20, in <module>
    ident2.resolveWithMib(view)
  File "/Users/eugene.kim/venvs/playground36/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pysnmp-4.4.1-py3.6.egg/pysnmp/smi/rfc1902.py", line 450, in resolveWithMib
  File "<string>", line 1223, in getIndicesFromInstId
pysnmp.smi.error.SmiError: Excessive instance identifier sub-OIDs left at MibTableRow((1, 3, 6, 1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 1), None): 177
```

Note:

- The OID-encoded `atNetAddress` `143.248.1.177` lacks the `NetworkAddress` type selector value `1` at the beginning;
- The buggy code could not resolve a correctly encoded index (`ident2`) because it did not expect the `NetworkAddress` type selector value before the IP address literal.  What happened instead is: 1) the buggy code erroneously decoded the address as `1.143.248.1` (the type selector value plus the first 3 sub-identifiers of the IP address), then 2) raised an exception upon seeing 177, which the last octet of the IP address.

#87 fixes this issue (note: #87 requires etingof/pyasn1#85), to yield correct result:

```

2017-10-06 10:49:52,256 pysnmp: resolved ('RFC1213-MIB', 'atIfIndex', 7, IpAddress(hexValue='8ff801b1')) into prefix ObjectName('1.3.6.1.2.1.3.1.1.1') and suffix ()

2017-10-06 10:49:52,257 pysnmp: resolved indices are (Integer32(7), NetworkAddress().setComponentByPosition(0, IpAddress(hexValue='8ff801b1')))
```

items.title: [PATCH] Rendering of implied string indices still broken
items.body:
Commit 30167082cd3f2706f733168da8647bbc4126696d fixes OID-to-syntax rendering of string indices, except for implied indices (used in `DISMAN-EVENT-MIB::mteEventTable`, for example).

PySNMP version: etingof/master commit 7404925300505fd8931cd227874465c417ac086e

To reproduce:

```
import pysnmp.debug
from pysnmp.smi.builder import MibBuilder
from pysnmp.smi.compiler import addMibCompiler
from pysnmp.smi.view import MibViewController
from pysnmp.smi.rfc1902 import ObjectIdentity
import user

builder = MibBuilder()
addMibCompiler(builder)
builder.loadModules('DISMAN-EVENT-MIB')
view = MibViewController(builder)

pysnmp.debug.setLogger(pysnmp.debug.Debug('all'))

ident = ObjectIdentity('DISMAN-EVENT-MIB', 'mteEventComment',
                       '_snmpd', '_linkDown')
ident.resolveWithMib(view)
ident2 = ObjectIdentity(ident.getOid())
ident2.resolveWithMib(view)
print(ident2.getMibSymbol())
```

items.title: [PATCH] asyncio cmdgen-s let exceptions fall through to the base event loop; commands hang
items.body:
When an object retrieved by an asyncio cmdgen fails to get resolved and raises `SmiError`, the exception is not caught by the cmdgen's callback and passed to the future, resulting in two things:

- The exception is caught by the asyncio base event loop instead, which reports it on the standard error;
- The original caller of the cmdgen hangs forever, because the cmdgen's future is left unmet.

PR #82 fixes this issue.
